headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2010 PPG Industries Earnings Conference Call. My name is Ronda and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Vince
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2010 PPG Industries Earnings Conference Call. My name is Ronda and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Vince Morales, Vice President Investor Relations. Please proceed, sir.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ronda. Good afternoon. This is Vince Morales, Vice President of Investor Relations for PPG Industries. Welcome to PPG's fourth quarter 2010 financial teleconference.Joining me on the call today from PPG is Chuck Bunch, Chairman of the Board a
componenttext:
Thank you, Ronda. Good afternoon. This is Vince Morales, Vice President of Investor Relations for PPG Industries. Welcome to PPG's fourth quarter 2010 financial teleconference.
Joining me on the call today from PPG is Chuck Bunch, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer; Bob Dellinger, Senior Vice President finance and Chief Financial Officer; and David Navikas, Vice President and Controller. 
Our comments relate to the financial information released on Thursday, January 20, 2011. As a reminder to everyone, and as we communicated last quarter, we have modified our quarterly earnings call process. Approximately one hour ago, we posted detailed commentary in the company presentation slides on our investor center at www.ppg.com. Slides are also in view available on the website for this call. We will not read those compared remarks during this call.
During the call, Chuck will share his perspective on the company's results for the fourth quarter and full year and then we will move directly to Q&A. The modified process will allow substantially more time for Q&A.
Both the prepared commentary and discussion during this call may contain forward-looking statements reflecting the company's current view about future events and their potential effect on PPG's operating and financial performance. These statements involve uncertainties and risks which may cause actual results to differ from such forward-looking statements. The company is under no obligation to provide subsequent updates to these forward-looking statements.
This presentation also contains certain non-GAAP financial measures. The company has provided in the appendix of the presentation materials which are also available under our website, reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measure. For additional information, please refer to PPG's filings with the SEC.
Lastly before we begin, I will remind you that we held a detailed capital markets analyst day in mid-december 2010. The presentation slides for that event contain further details about our industry, businesses and used markets. And those slides are again available on our website. 
Now let me introduce PPG's Chairman and CEO, Chuck Bunch.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Vince and welcome, everyone. PPG posted record sales and earnings per share this quarter, capping off an excellent 2010 full year performance. We achieved record fourth quarter sales on strong price and volume gains and despite continued curren
componenttext:
Thank you, Vince and welcome, everyone. PPG posted record sales and earnings per share this quarter, capping off an excellent 2010 full year performance. We achieved record fourth quarter sales on strong price and volume gains and despite continued currency headwinds. Our sales in local currencies grew by 10% year-over-year. Our broadening businesses and emerge in emerging regions once again delivered double-digit sales growth including in Asia where our sales this quarter grew by more than 15%.
Also, for the full year, I'm very pleased to report that our Asia Pacific region surpassed $2 billion in sales, up nearly 25% with strong earnings growth approaching 50%. We leveraged the higher sales, delivering record fourth quarter earnings per share. The global economic recovery began to take gain traction during the fourth quarter of 2009, making this quarter's year-over-year comparison more relevant. So our 50% year-over-year earnings per share increased is meaningful.
In addition to the volume gains, another factor in the fourth quarter was higher selling prices. In the quarter, every one of our segments delivered higher pricing versus last year. In looking at the year in total, the company's pricing has increased in each quarter during the year. 
In our Coatings business is, these higher prices offset or minimize margin oppression compression from inflating raw materials cost. Coatings raw material inflation began to escalate in the middle of 2010 and remained at persistently high levels through the fourth quarter.
In our Commodity Chemicals and Glass segments, pricing gains were a contributor to the segment earnings recovery trends and were driven by higher demand as the end-used markets continue to recover.
Also, despite the ongoing recovery, we have continued aggressive management of our operations and overall cost structure. In 2010, our operating segments reduced cost by $100 million from our prior restructuring actions, plus an additional $50 million plus from other manufacturing and cost management initiatives. This $150 million of savings is an in addition to the $350 million we delivered in 2009, resulting in over $500 million of lower cost in comparison with 2008.
Looking at our performance on a segment basis, we posted record fourth quarter segment earnings, easily eclipsing our prior record by more than 15%. Our combined Coatings and Optical and Specialty Materials segments also delivered both record sales and earnings in the quarter.
Our broad geographic Coatings footprint enabled us to take advantage of continuing improvements in overall global industrial activity and continued expansion in aftermarket activity levels.
In Optical and Specialty Materials, we once again drove excellent topline growth and maintained our trend this year of expanding year-over-year margins. In what is typically a seasonally slow period, weak construction and maintenance markets continue to weigh on our Architectural Coatings business in Europe, although our Architectural Coatings volumes in our U.S. and Canada business were essentially flat with the prior year.
Our performance Coatings and Optical and Specialty Materials segments, both top margin performers for PPG, also delivered fourth quarter earnings records and have continued future growth prospects.
Architectural Coatings EMEA earnings declined due to weakness in market demand. Also, our Industrial Coatings segment results were lower as price, volumes and costs improved, but not sufficiently enough to fully offset inflation.
As a benchmark, in past inflationary cycles in Coatings, it has taken two to three quarters for our pricing initiatives to fully calendar inflationary impacts. We have additional pricing increases being implemented in 2011, and I am confident we are on pace to fully counteract inflation in our Coatings businesses in the first half of 2011. Also, as in the past, our Commodity Chemicals segment is once again serving as a hedge to inflationary pressures impacting our Coatings businesses. Segment margins grew to over 19% this quarter as the earnings improvement trend continued due to higher pricing. In addition, our last segment earnings also improved substantially, driven by higher end-use market activity coupled with our continued cost management actions.
In 2011, these businesses should continue to benefit from tight market conditions and lower natural gas cost as our prior year's higher cost hedges will roll off.
Fourth quarter earnings for the Commodity Chemicals and Glass segments combined improved by over $90 million versus last year. This performance, along with the combined record Coatings and Optical and Specialty Materials segment earnings were key factors in our record fourth quarter earnings per share. This is the second consecutive quarter that we delivered record earnings.
Overall for 2010, I was very satisfied with our performance. We fully capitalized on the partial economic recovery, maintained our sharp focus on cost management, and leveraged our global breadth and global leadership position in our businesses.
Also, we extended our legacy of returning cash to shareholders by returning about 75% of our cash from operations, or nearly $1 billion to shareholders in the form of an increased annual dividend payout and share repurchases. Our record second-half earnings performance and near-record full year earnings demonstrate how strongly we are emerging from the recession. This performance is despite full year volumes that were still $1.2 billion below pre-recession 2008 levels, including continued anemic activity levels in construction markets in the mature regions.
We are only now beginning to see the full earnings power of the company and we are carrying this momentum forward into 2011 when we anticipate recovery in the global economy to strengthen and broaden. This should drive volume increases for PPG, which we expect to leverage at high margins as we continue to manage our costs. We anticipate that our strong emerging regions penetration and several of our leading businesses like Optical products and Aerospace will continue to serve as significant growth drivers.
Also, as I mentioned previously at the outset of the year, we are implementing a variety of selling price increases throughout our portfolio with the objective of offsetting Coatings margin compression and furthering our commodity chemicals earnings improvement trend.
Finally, we are working on initiatives to deploy the nearly $2 billion we have in cash and short-term investments with a focus on growing earnings and increasing shareholder returns. 
That concludes our prepared remarks. Now operator, would you please give instructions and open the phone lines for questions?

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Bob Koort from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Bob Koort from Goldman Sachs.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Chuck, can talk a little bit about the sequencing you see of raw material inflation? I know in the December event you talked about particularly in Coatings, the first half, some supply availability issues and in the second half TIA 02. I guess her e in re
componenttext: Chuck, can talk a little bit about the sequencing you see of raw material inflation? I know in the December event you talked about particularly in Coatings, the first half, some supply availability issues and in the second half TIA 02. I guess her e in recent weeks, we started to see oil reaches new highs and maybe putting some pressure on the raw materials slate as you go into '11. Can you just talk a little bit about the dynamics between price and cost as we go through the year?

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the cost of raw materials, we averaged in Coatings, mid-single-digit increases for 2010, Bob. But obviously, that built so we were ending the fourth quarter year in 2010, those were in a the higher single-digits and we, in terms of percentage increases
componenttext: On the cost of raw materials, we averaged in Coatings, mid-single-digit increases for 2010, Bob. But obviously, that built so we were ending the fourth quarter year in 2010, those were in a the higher single-digits and we, in terms of percentage increases -- and we saw it across a broad range of products. And we didn't see quite as many, although there were still some supply disruptions, but you had it on both the organic and inorganic sides, the TI2 being one of them, other pigments, we had some of the medals play a role in our formulations in Protective & Marine Coatings. There were also up. Now starting here in 2011, we're seeing a little additional raw material pressure, I would say at this point, this would be low-single-digit increases, but on top of where we finished at the end of 2010. So we are still facing some headwinds here on the raw material inflation for Coatings. We have started raising our prices starting in midyear of last year, working through some of them, but actually the inflationary numbers have continued to move. So in every one of our businesses today, we have additional pricing actions. In some, we have some formal price increases out in others we are actively negotiating with customers to pass these price increases on. And as I have mentioned in the remarks, typically it does take two to three quarters to fully capture all of these inflationary price increases. I think the fact that we have a little bit of a moving target means that we're still in price increase mode in our businesses. But we're looking, as we go through 2011, to fully capture those price increases. And we don't, in terms of the current forecast, we don't think things are going to accelerate as aggressively as they did last year. But we are seeing the same trends that you mentioned. Oil prices are up. And we've seen recent increases in commodities like TiO2 or propylene. But on the other hand, we haven't seen as much recent increases in natural gas, in ethylene as an example. So right now, we are expecting more inflation for our Coatings raw materials, but not quite at the pace we saw in the second half last year.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: You had a slide in your deck that I thought was pretty compelling, showing how much earnings power there still is from a volume recovery, given your still quite a bit below where you were before. Just curious, how do you internally measure cost versus tha
componenttext: You had a slide in your deck that I thought was pretty compelling, showing how much earnings power there still is from a volume recovery, given your still quite a bit below where you were before. Just curious, how do you internally measure cost versus that volume recovery that you look forward? And maybe talk a little bit about how you would size the margin opportunity in your businesses, some of which are already pretty darn high. But it looks like there's still a lot of volume leverage on the pipeline.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: For us, our variable cost margins typically run between 40% and 50%, depending on the business unit and the geographic regions. So certainly, we think that we have that kind of opportunity to improve as the volume grows but we don't think we have signific
componenttext: For us, our variable cost margins typically run between 40% and 50%, depending on the business unit and the geographic regions. So certainly, we think that we have that kind of opportunity to improve as the volume grows but we don't think we have significant cost to put back in to our supply chains and our businesses. We are still running in many businesses, especially in Coatings with the exception of where we are today in China. For the most part, we have capacity available in our Coatings businesses to a fully capture the incremental margins at variable cost. So we're relatively optimistic that this can be done as volumes improved.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011

componenttext: Chuck, on raws, could you actually size the delta that you think you might see in both Q1 or the first half of the year between raw and some of the price increases to bring forth?

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. I would say obviously if you look overall at PPG, we don't think there's an issue at all with the increases that we're seeing across the board in all of our business units. And we're obviously going to outpace inflation in businesses like Fiberglass o
componenttext: No. I would say obviously if you look overall at PPG, we don't think there's an issue at all with the increases that we're seeing across the board in all of our business units. And we're obviously going to outpace inflation in businesses like Fiberglass or chlor-alkali. I would say that for the Coatings businesses, we think it would be a relatively small number. We are obviously chasing some of the increases that we just talked about. But we feel fairly confident that as the year proceeds, we're going to be able to recapture a lot of these increases with pricing.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: And Chuck, just on Glass, had a very strong back half of the year, is that $60 million EBIT number of the back half, is that the run rate going forward for the full year 2011?
componenttext: And Chuck, just on Glass, had a very strong back half of the year, is that $60 million EBIT number of the back half, is that the run rate going forward for the full year 2011?

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say that typically, the fourth quarter is not the strongest quarter for the Glass segment. We think that the earnings improvement that we've seen, especially in Fiberglass, should be sustainable. As we go into 2011, we've talked a little bit about
componenttext: I would say that typically, the fourth quarter is not the strongest quarter for the Glass segment. We think that the earnings improvement that we've seen, especially in Fiberglass, should be sustainable. As we go into 2011, we've talked a little bit about some of the pricing opportunities. We haven't seen the same kind of raw material inflation impacting those businesses. The flat Glass business, Performance Glazings, as we've called it, has not had the same recovery yet because it is tied to the North American construction markets. But even there, I think we've certainly view that we've hit bottom and we think that they're maybe some modest upside. So I think the run rate is actually a good number as we start here in 2011.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rex Ryan with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rex Ryan with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Frank Mitsch sitting in for Rex Ryan. As PPG is progress, you obviously the comps got more difficult and you start out with 12% volume growth copy in the year ending up with 5% at the end of the year. So as you look out in 2011, the commentary in
componenttext: This is Frank Mitsch sitting in for Rex Ryan. As PPG is progress, you obviously the comps got more difficult and you start out with 12% volume growth copy in the year ending up with 5% at the end of the year. So as you look out in 2011, the commentary in the release was fairly upbeat in terms of the global economic environment. What sort of volume forecasts are you looking at something that single-digits in terms of volume increases off of a decent 2010? How would you characterize that environment out there?

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say that's a good number, Frank, especially on the industrial production side. We're probably going to be here in North America at that level. Certainly in Asia, little higher, maybe slightly lower on the industrial production side. So I'd say mid
componenttext: I would say that's a good number, Frank, especially on the industrial production side. We're probably going to be here in North America at that level. Certainly in Asia, little higher, maybe slightly lower on the industrial production side. So I'd say mid single-digits is a good number. The thing that's holding us back still has been the weakness in construction markets, both here and North America and in Europe. I'm getting slightly more optimistic, although I've felt this way before and hasn't followed through, but I think the North American businesses that have that construction exposure will actually, I think will begin to show some improvement as we go through the year. Europe, it's a little foggier over there. We haven't seen much volume improvement, so I'm a little less optimistic that Europe construction will help us. But overall, when I look out across the board, on our Optical segment, when I look at even for our call and the volume side, I think those are the numbers across the board.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: With respect to Europe, you indicated that it was quite stable in terms of the decline in volumes that you saw 2010 versus '09. Would you think that we've stabilize here or would you continue to see volume erosion in Europe?
componenttext: With respect to Europe, you indicated that it was quite stable in terms of the decline in volumes that you saw 2010 versus '09. Would you think that we've stabilize here or would you continue to see volume erosion in Europe?

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think things are getting, let's call it worse in terms of kind of rate of decline. But we still haven't seen this thing flatten out in terms of volume declines in Europe construction. We have in our other businesses in Europe, and in fact in some
componenttext: I don't think things are getting, let's call it worse in terms of kind of rate of decline. But we still haven't seen this thing flatten out in terms of volume declines in Europe construction. We have in our other businesses in Europe, and in fact in some businesses like Automotive refinished in Europe, we had done all-time record year. So I don't want to overstate our reliance on the architectural EMEA businesses, it's an important business for us, it hasn't started turning yet. But I would say the rate of decline I expect to improve in that business during the course of the year. And we are still seeing growth overall in businesses like refinished or Aerospace, or even protective Coatings in Europe. So it's not all gloom and doom over there, but certainly, that's the weakest region right now for us.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Lastly, you did a transaction with Dominion recently. That's your nature in West Virginia facility. Can you comment on what the benefits are to PPG would expect to that transaction and more broadly, what type of transaction should I be looking at now that
componenttext: Lastly, you did a transaction with Dominion recently. That's your nature in West Virginia facility. Can you comment on what the benefits are to PPG would expect to that transaction and more broadly, what type of transaction should I be looking at now that your balance sheet has really been showing up here.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well the transaction with Dominion was really facilitating I guess you call it there building of the natural gas liquids separation plant. And at the West Virginia panhandle end of the Marcellus Shale, as many of you know, this is the -- wet natural gas,
componenttext: Well the transaction with Dominion was really facilitating I guess you call it there building of the natural gas liquids separation plant. And at the West Virginia panhandle end of the Marcellus Shale, as many of you know, this is the -- wet natural gas, let's call it. And we're hoping this is an overall stimulus, not only for the economy down there but I think there's some real opportunities to build on the low-cost cheap natural gas in the region. We're going to get, I think, some small improvement in terms of providing services to them. We're going to sell some land that we no longer need. But we're also looking for other opportunities at that site, as is our bear who is our neighbor in West Virginia, for opportunities to capitalize on this Marcellus Shale gas that sits underneath the region, including our plants.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011

componenttext: This is Dan Jester sitting in for PJ. I was just wondering, architectural paint volumes were flat in the U.S. Are you seeing any different trends in the contractor market versus DIY?

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say at this point, no. The fourth quarter is the seasonally low period. It's hard to discern a lot of trends, I'd say. I wouldn't want to put too much on a segment by channel differentiation, but we are encouraged that overall the volumes were sta
componenttext: I would say at this point, no. The fourth quarter is the seasonally low period. It's hard to discern a lot of trends, I'd say. I wouldn't want to put too much on a segment by channel differentiation, but we are encouraged that overall the volumes were stable. And I actually think now that we may see some improvement in volume as we go through the year. Some of the housing data, although it's still mixed, is encouraging. The weather is going to be a little cold here starting off this year. But I'm getting a little more optimistic about the volume scenario right now.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say that our store count is going to be flat or slightly higher, but it won't be lower. So we continue I think to right-size the footprint and I would think going forward especially as we get a little more confident that this housing market is not
componenttext: I would say that our store count is going to be flat or slightly higher, but it won't be lower. So we continue I think to right-size the footprint and I would think going forward especially as we get a little more confident that this housing market is not going to get any worse that we have the store count that will work for us as business improves.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Douglas with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Douglas with KeyBanc.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: First on the volumes, you mentioned that sales volumes still remain about $1.2 billion below I guess the 2008 peak levels. Can you give us a sense how this breaks down by the various businesses, where you see the greatest near-term opportunities to recapt
componenttext: First on the volumes, you mentioned that sales volumes still remain about $1.2 billion below I guess the 2008 peak levels. Can you give us a sense how this breaks down by the various businesses, where you see the greatest near-term opportunities to recapture volumes?

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well the biggest opportunities would be in the developed regions in the Industrial and Performance Coatings segments. Although we feel good about the growth in automotive builds here in North America, we still only got up to about 12.5 million builds in 2
componenttext: Well the biggest opportunities would be in the developed regions in the Industrial and Performance Coatings segments. Although we feel good about the growth in automotive builds here in North America, we still only got up to about 12.5 million builds in 2010. That's still about 20% below what was the run rate for most of this decade here in North America. So that's an example of an industrial market, where there is more growth opportunities. Similarly, in Europe, we didn't go quite as low there, but there is Automotive growth potential there, although we're not as optimistic in Europe in automotive as we are here in North America. The other big sets of businesses would be those related to the construction markets. Obviously, we have exposure both here and in North America in both residential and commercial construction. And also in the, let's call it the residential repaint or the aftermarkets for maintenance and repair, we're still below the volumes that we experienced just three years ago. So that would be another opportunity where we see the volumes improving. But in the short term, it's going to be in the more industrial markets, plus those Performance Coatings like Aerospace which is, I think, ramping up now; refinish which experienced quite as sharp decline in 2009, it's bouncing back. This winter whether that we are all experiencing this last six weeks should help us in terms of accident rates in the near future. So those are terms that give me confidence that we have plenty of opportunities, even here in 2011 to recapture some of this lost volume over the last three years.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Secondly, did I hear you correctly that the incremental margins or somewhere in the neighborhood of 40% to 50% depending on the businesses?
componenttext: Secondly, did I hear you correctly that the incremental margins or somewhere in the neighborhood of 40% to 50% depending on the businesses?

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say that's a good benchmark. It does vary. But typically, most of our businesses are more what I would describe as materially intensive. They are not as labor intensive so we don't have to add big increments of labor cost as we increase production
componenttext: I would say that's a good benchmark. It does vary. But typically, most of our businesses are more what I would describe as materially intensive. They are not as labor intensive so we don't have to add big increments of labor cost as we increase production.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011

componenttextpreview: Question on the commodity business and chlor-alkali and in particular, just wondering if you can be more specific on what kind of price increases you had in the fourth quarter and typically how much of that last $50 industry price increase you realized an
componenttext: Question on the commodity business and chlor-alkali and in particular, just wondering if you can be more specific on what kind of price increases you had in the fourth quarter and typically how much of that last $50 industry price increase you realized and what sort of price point in you're expecting in the first quarter. And I guess compared to your average gas acquisition cost of $5.50 in 2010 and this undercurrent hedging position on the strip, where would you expect gas costs to come out in '11? That is what kind of benefit you think you could get from being less hedged compared to last year?

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: First question, Don, commodity chemical pricing in particular cost at. We were working through the last industry price increase of $50. We captured some of that in the fourth quarter, and we think we will finish capturing that here in the first quarter of
componenttext: First question, Don, commodity chemical pricing in particular cost at. We were working through the last industry price increase of $50. We captured some of that in the fourth quarter, and we think we will finish capturing that here in the first quarter of 2011. And there's momentum in the marketplace, volumes have been good, inventories are low, several of the key end use markets like aluminum and pulp and paper, refining have already been picking up activity levels we haven't seen any additional pricing from the end of the year increase that one of the competitors announced. But certainly, the one that was $50 that you referenced at the beginning of the fourth quarter is still moving through the system.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: And gas costs?
componenttext: And gas costs?

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, our blended unit cost in the first quarter was about five dollars. If you look at our hedges for 2011, on average, we have about 12% of our needs hedged and that's greater in the first half, lower in the second half and that hedge position us about s
componenttext: Yes, our blended unit cost in the first quarter was about five dollars. If you look at our hedges for 2011, on average, we have about 12% of our needs hedged and that's greater in the first half, lower in the second half and that hedge position us about some $7 on the quarter. So make your assumption that market price to get pretty close.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin McCarthy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin McCarthy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: You made a comment in the transcript on the website that you'd anticipate returning cash and short term investments back towards historic levels in 2011 versus the December 31 level approaching $2 billion. And I was wondering can you just comment on I gue
componenttext: You made a comment in the transcript on the website that you'd anticipate returning cash and short term investments back towards historic levels in 2011 versus the December 31 level approaching $2 billion. And I was wondering can you just comment on I guess A, with that historical level is. If I look back to the '06, '07 timeframe you were running the balance sheet with about $500 million in cash which would imply you could take it down $1.5 billion then be as you proceed down that path, how are you thinking about M&A and the pace of share repurchases?

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Kevin now be happy to take that. I think $.5 billion is pretty historical we get through over some period of time. Our first goal for deploying cash is obviously to drive earnings growth in our preference would be mergers and acquisitions. And we've talke
componenttext: Kevin now be happy to take that. I think $.5 billion is pretty historical we get through over some period of time. Our first goal for deploying cash is obviously to drive earnings growth in our preference would be mergers and acquisitions. And we've talked a lot in the past about bolt-on acquisitions in the, call it $50 million to $250 million range. And I think as we regularly evaluate the pipeline and probability of those deals closing and crossing the real consider share repurchases if we don't see sufficient acquisition activity over time. We certainly don't have any pre-determined goal by quarter of the targeted cash balance or how quickly we're going to get back to historic levels. But that's the direction you should expect.

componenttext: And then as a follow-up, with regard to capital expenditures, you spent $158 million the first nine months of 2010, and then nearly that amount or $150 million just in fourth quarter. You've always been somewhat back-end loaded there, but it strikes me perhaps more pronounced seasonally than usual. Could you comment on what's driving that and what the outlook is for 2011 there?

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll be happy to take the fourth quarter question. We've made some progress in spending in China. As you know, we've been working on a resin plant in. We have production expansion going on in Wu Hu, some transitions expenditures and state China. And i thi
componenttext: I'll be happy to take the fourth quarter question. We've made some progress in spending in China. As you know, we've been working on a resin plant in. We have production expansion going on in Wu Hu, some transitions expenditures and state China. And i think those are probably pretty significant drivers of the increase in the fourth quarter. I think we've talked a fair amount at the December investor conference about our outlook for capital going forward, and I would expect we're still in that range.

componenttextpreview: Marine business for us, it's part of our Protective & Marine Coatings business unit. For us, the Marine OEM segment, which we're looking for what I would call the first decline in this kind of late cycle building would be in that 25% of SVU that is expose
componenttext: Marine business for us, it's part of our Protective & Marine Coatings business unit. For us, the Marine OEM segment, which we're looking for what I would call the first decline in this kind of late cycle building would be in that 25% of SVU that is exposed to the OEM builds. The other half of that Protective & Marine Coatings business is infrastructure or protective Coatings-related. There, you're painting bridges, you're painting oil rigs and the like. We think of that business is going to be good, and we also think the aftermarket business for Marine is going to be improved over last year. You have more of these ocean going vessels in service now. They're requiring maintenance and training. So I would say overall, we think there's going to be a low growth environment in 2011 with the aftermarket at protective pieces overshadowing that Marine OEM build number.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011

componenttext: My second question, you commented that cost-savings were $150 million for 2010. How much of that was in fourth quarter and what are your expectations for cost-savings in 2011?

componenttextpreview: I'd be happy to add. Let me -- I think the easiest way to think about our cost-savings is if you compare full year 2010 to 2008, we would say our costs are down roughly $500 million. Half of that,  so to say $250 million, was driven by the restructuring p
componenttext: I'd be happy to add. Let me -- I think the easiest way to think about our cost-savings is if you compare full year 2010 to 2008, we would say our costs are down roughly $500 million. Half of that,  so to say $250 million, was driven by the restructuring projects, and that is permanent cost-savings. We'll experienced even his volume comes back. A part of the remaining $250 million of other actions consistent with the decline in market, part of that will come back as volume returns. Maybe in the neighborhood of 1/3 to 1/2. volume returns to over eight levels. And that's what you should expect going forward. Most of the cost-savings we have realized before we got to the fourth quarter of this year, of 2010.

componenttext: I would say the business in Asia in industrial Coatings is fairly broad-based in terms of the technologies or Coatings layers. So it's not all driven by e-coat. We've had excellent growth in non-e-coat or even automotive related businesses like consumer electronics. And I would say our success in the China automotive Coatings market is broad-based. So it's not just e-coat, it includes the top coats and primers so that -- and this is not one-time pipeline so for eco-tanks, although we are doing that on a consistent basis with both automotive and some of our industrial applications.

componenttext: I would say that our list -- and we talked a little bit about this in our capital markets presentation last month. The list is probably a little broader or longer. And frankly, we were able to the one deal in the fourth quarter of last year. We would have like to have done a few more. It's taking a little longer. And I would say in regards to the list, its probably longer, but they're probably more weighted to the smaller end of the spectrum in terms of the overall size of the acquisition. So before going to maintain our target level of use of cash for good M&A, we may have to do more deals. But these deals would be at smaller levels than maybe we originally thought as we started ramping up at the beginning of 2010.

componenttext: There has not been that many overall deals. If I look, all of the major Coatings players look like they're interested in doing deals. There were only a few deals last year that were completed, and I think it was, in some cases, the seller is waiting a little longer for things to get a little better. If they think that there have some earnings momentum in other cases -- as you go to smaller companies in some cases, there is a longer time period to get into certain stages in the deals, getting people comfortable with the process, whereas sometimes when we've done bigger deals, you have more sophisticated or experienced management teams on both sides of the table. And as you go into smaller opportunities, it is a longer process.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: The margins that we have now in the business we think are sustainable at these levels. We're not necessarily looking to expand these margins significantly from this point. It is a business, especially on the Optical side where we have driven growth over t
componenttext: The margins that we have now in the business we think are sustainable at these levels. We're not necessarily looking to expand these margins significantly from this point. It is a business, especially on the Optical side where we have driven growth over the years in a combination of the technology, developments and branding activities, including heavy component of advertising. So as we look at how we're going to grow the business, I would say that we want to keep a certain level of advertising and promotional spending. But we have to support these new product development and commercialization activities. So we're not -- we feel the biggest opportunity for growth in the segment is growing that top line at the existing margin levels. But likewise, we don't see a significant risk to these margins declining. We have seen it to be sustained over the last few years, and we think that the specialty materials component of that segment, the precipitated silicas and the Tesla inorganic printing sheet materials have improved their performance significantly over the last two years, but we think to a sustainable level.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2010 PPG Industries Earnings Conference Call. My name is Tuwanda and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions]  I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Vin
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2010 PPG Industries Earnings Conference Call. My name is Tuwanda and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions]  I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Vince Morales, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please proceed, sir.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tuwanda. Good afternoon. This is Vince Morales, Vice President of Investor Relations for PPG Industries. Welcome to PPG's Fourth Quarter 2010 Financial Teleconference.Joining me on the call today from PPG is Chuck Bunch, Chairman of the Board
componenttext:
Thank you, Tuwanda. Good afternoon. This is Vince Morales, Vice President of Investor Relations for PPG Industries. Welcome to PPG's Fourth Quarter 2010 Financial Teleconference.
Joining me on the call today from PPG is Chuck Bunch, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer; Bob Dellinger, Senior Vice President, Finance and Chief Financial Officer; and Dave Navikas, Vice President and Controller. 
Our comments relate to the financial information released on Thursday, January 20, 2011. As a reminder to everyone, and as we communicated last quarter, we have modified our quarterly earnings call process. Approximately one hour ago, we posted detailed commentary in the company presentation slides on our Investor Center at ppg.com. Slides are also available on the webcast site for this call. We will not read those prepared remarks during this call.
During the call, Chuck will share his perspective on the company's results for the fourth quarter and full year and then we will move directly to Q&A. The modified process will allow substantially more time for Q&A.
Both the prepared commentary and discussion during this call may contain forward-looking statements reflecting the company's current view about future events and their potential effect on PPG's operating and financial performance. These statements involve uncertainties and risks which may cause actual results to differ from such forward-looking statements. The company is under no obligation to provide subsequent updates to these forward-looking statements. This presentation also contains certain non-GAAP financial measures the company has provided in the appendix of the presentation materials, which are also available under our website, reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly-comparable GAAP financial measures. For additional information, please refer to PPG's filings with the SEC.
Lastly before we begin, I will remind you that we held a detailed Capital Markets Analyst Day in mid-December 2010. The presentation slides for that event contain further details about our industry, businesses and then news [ph] markets. And those slides again, are available on our website. 
Now let me introduce PPG's Chairman CEO, Chuck Bunch.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Vince, and welcome, everyone. PPG posted record sales and earnings per share this quarter, capping off an excellent 2010 full-year performance. We achieved record fourth quarter sales on strong price and volume gains. And despite continued curr
componenttext:
Thank you, Vince, and welcome, everyone. PPG posted record sales and earnings per share this quarter, capping off an excellent 2010 full-year performance. We achieved record fourth quarter sales on strong price and volume gains. And despite continued currency headwinds, our sales in local currencies grew by 10% year-over-year. Our broadening businesses in emerging regions once again delivered double-digit sales growth including in Asia, where our sales this quarter grew by more than 15%.
Also, for the full year, I am very pleased to report that our Asia-Pacific region surpassed $2 billion in sales, up nearly 25% with strong earnings growth approaching 50%. We leveraged the higher sales, delivering record fourth quarter earnings per share. The global economic recovery began to gain traction during the fourth quarter of 2009, making this quarter's year-over-year comparison more relevant. So our 50% year-over-year earnings per share increase is meaningful.
In addition to the volume gains, another factor in the fourth quarter was higher selling prices. In the quarter, every one of our segments delivered higher pricing versus last year. In looking at the year in total, the company's pricing has increased in each quarter during the year. 
In our Coatings businesses, these higher prices offset or minimized margin compression from inflating raw material cost. Coatings' raw material inflation began to escalate in the middle of 2010 and remained at persistently high levels through the fourth quarter.
In our Commodity Chemicals and Glass segments, pricing gains were a contributor to the segment earnings recovery trends and were driven by higher demand as the end-use markets continued to recover.
Also, despite the ongoing recovery, we have continued aggressive management of our operations and overall cost structure. In 2010, our operating segments reduced cost by $100 million from our prior restructuring actions, plus an additional $50 million plus from other manufacturing and cost management initiatives. This $150 million of savings is in addition to the $350 million we delivered in 2009, resulting in over $500 million of lower cost in comparison with 2008.
Looking at our performance on a segment basis, we posted record fourth quarter segment earnings, easily eclipsing our prior record by more than 15%. Our combined Coatings and Optical and Specialty Materials segments also delivered both record sales and earnings in the quarter. Our broad geographic Coatings footprint enabled us to take advantage of continuing improvements in overall global industrial activity and continued expansion in aftermarket activity levels. 
In Optical and Specialty Materials, we once again drove excellent topline growth and maintained our trend this year of expanding year-over-year margins. In what is typically a seasonally slow period, weak construction and maintenance markets continued to weigh on our Architectural Coatings business in Europe, although our Architectural Coatings volumes in our U.S. and Canada business were essentially flat with the prior year. Our performance Coatings and Optical and Specialty Materials segments, both top margin performers for PPG, also delivered fourth quarter earnings records and have continued future growth prospects. Architectural Coatings' EMEA earnings declined due to weakness in market demand. Also, our Industrial Coatings segment results were lower as price, volumes and costs improved, but not sufficiently enough to fully offset inflation.
As a benchmark in past inflationary cycles in Coatings, it has taken two to three quarters for our pricing initiatives to fully counter inflationary impacts. We have additional pricing increases being implemented in 2011, and I am confident we are on pace to fully counteract inflation in our Coatings businesses in the first half of 2011. Also, as in the past, our Commodity Chemicals segment is once again serving as a hedge to inflationary pressures impacting our Coatings businesses. Segment margins grew to over 19% this quarter as the earnings improvement trend continued due to higher pricing. In addition, our Glass segment earnings also improved substantially, driven by higher end-use market activity coupled with our continued cost management actions. In 2011, these businesses should continue to benefit from tight market conditions and lower natural gas cost as our prior year's higher cost hedges will roll off.
Fourth quarter earnings for the Commodity Chemicals and Glass segments combined, improved by over $90 million versus last year. This performance, along with the combined record Coatings and Optical and Specialty Materials segment earnings were key factors in our record fourth quarter earnings per share. This is the second consecutive quarter that we delivered record earnings.
Overall for 2010, I was very satisfied with our performance. We fully capitalized on the partial economic recovery, maintained our sharp focus on cost management, and leveraged our global breadth and leadership positions in our businesses. Also, we extended our legacy of returning cash to shareholders by returning about 75% of our cash from operations, or nearly $1 billion, to shareholders in the form of an increased annual dividend payout and share repurchases. Our record second-half earnings performance and near-record full year earnings demonstrate how strongly we are emerging from the recession. This performance is despite full-year volumes that were still $1.2 billion below pre-recession 2008 levels, including continued anemic activity levels in construction markets in the mature regions.
We are only now beginning to see the full earnings power of the company and we are carrying this momentum forward into 2011, when we anticipate recovery in the global economy to strengthen and broaden. This should drive volume increases for PPG, which we expect to leverage at high margins as we continue to manage our costs. We anticipate that our strong emerging regions penetration and several of our leading businesses, like Optical products and Aerospace, will continue to serve as significant growth drivers. Also, as I mentioned previously at the outset of the year, we are implementing a variety of selling price increases throughout our portfolio with the objective of offsetting Coatings margin compression and furthering our Commodity Chemicals earnings improvement trend. Finally, we are working on initiatives to deploy the nearly $2 billion we have in cash and short-term investments with a focus on growing earnings and increasing shareholder returns. 
That concludes our prepared remarks. Now operator, would you please give instructions and open the phone lines for questions?

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Bob Koort with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Bob Koort with Goldman Sachs.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Chuck, can talk a little bit about the sequencing you see of raw material inflation? I know at the December event you talked about particularly in Coatings, the first half, some supply availability issues, and in the second half Ti02. But I guess here in
componenttext: Chuck, can talk a little bit about the sequencing you see of raw material inflation? I know at the December event you talked about particularly in Coatings, the first half, some supply availability issues, and in the second half Ti02. But I guess here in recent weeks, we started to see oil reaching some new highs and maybe putting some more pressure on the raw materials slate as you go into '11. So can you just talk a little bit about the dynamics between price and cost as we go through the year?

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the cost of raw materials, we averaged in Coatings, mid-single-digit increases for 2010, Bob. But obviously, that built, so that as we were ending the fourth quarter here in 2010, those were in the higher single-digits and we, in terms of percentage in
componenttext: On the cost of raw materials, we averaged in Coatings, mid-single-digit increases for 2010, Bob. But obviously, that built, so that as we were ending the fourth quarter here in 2010, those were in the higher single-digits and we, in terms of percentage increases -- then we saw it across a broad range of products. And we didn't see quite as many, although there were still some supply disruptions, but you had it on both the organic and inorganic sides, TiO2 being one of them. Other pigments, we had some of the metals which play a role in our formulations in Protective & Marine Coatings, they were also up. Now starting here in 2011, we're seeing a little additional raw material pressure. I would say at this point, this would be low-single-digit increases, but on top of where we finished at the end of 2010. So we are still facing some headwinds here on the raw material inflation for Coatings. We have started raising our prices starting in mid-year of last year, working through some of them, but actually the inflationary numbers have continued to move. So in every one of our businesses today, we have additional pricing actions. In some we have some formal price increase announcements out, in others we are actively negotiating with customers to pass these price increases on. And as I have mentioned in the remarks, typically it does take two to three quarters to fully capture all of these inflationary price increases. I think the fact that we have a little bit of a moving target means that we're still in price increase mode in our businesses. But we're looking, as we go through 2011, to fully capture those price increases. And we don't, in terms of the current forecast, we don't think things are going to accelerate as aggressively as they did last year, but we are seeing the same trends that you mentioned. Oil prices are up. And we've seen recent increases in commodities like TiO2 or propylene. But on the other hand, we haven't seen as much recent increases in natural gas, in ethylene as an example. So right now, we are expecting more inflation for our Coatings' raw materials, but not quite at the pace that we saw in the second half of the last year.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: You had a slide in your deck that I felt was pretty compelling, showing how much earnings power there still is from a volume recovery, given you're still quite a bit below where you were before. Just curious, how do you internally measure cost versus that
componenttext: You had a slide in your deck that I felt was pretty compelling, showing how much earnings power there still is from a volume recovery, given you're still quite a bit below where you were before. Just curious, how do you internally measure cost versus that volume recovery as you look forward? And maybe you can talk a little bit about how you would size the margin opportunity in your businesses, some of which are already pretty darn high. But it looks like there's a lot of volume leverage still in the pipeline.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: For us, our variable cost margins typically run between 40% and 50%, depending on the business unit and the geographic region. So certainly, we think that we have that kind of opportunity to improve as volume grows, but we don't think we have significant
componenttext: For us, our variable cost margins typically run between 40% and 50%, depending on the business unit and the geographic region. So certainly, we think that we have that kind of opportunity to improve as volume grows, but we don't think we have significant cost to put back in to our supply chains and our businesses. We are still running in many businesses, especially in Coatings with the exception of where we are today in China. For the most part, we have capacity available in our Coatings businesses to fully capture the incremental margins at variable costs. So we're relatively optimistic that this can be done as volumes improve.

headline: PPG Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Begleiter with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Begleiter with Deutsche Bank.
